bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, October 10, 1901
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

p.add: INDEX BUREAU REC'D. NOV 4 01 DEPT OF STATE.

div1.p: No. 83. Consular. Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, October 10, 1901.

p.add: Ack by Form 8 Copied with enclosures to auditor Nov 9/01

div1.p: Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State Washington.
Subject. Transmission of receipts for disbursements &c. in the settlement of the estate of the late William Parker.
No. 83. Consular. Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, October 10, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to say that the accompanying receipts, with a single exception, have just reached me, after dispatching my mail for the just steamer and bound, due here tomorrow; however in order, that you may have these receipts to compare with the disbersements in the William Parker case, I hasten to mail them to you, without having time to arrange them
them as I desire, with accompanying of transmitting dispatches.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith Consul General.
Enclosures. As above.
Copy. Copy of the Supt's Letter.
Supt's Department Territory G. C. Mount, Sept. 30, 1901.
Sir.,- Your communication of August 22, came to hand on the 27th instant with its contents.
I beg to state that I could not get one person to give me solid receipt for the amount as requested, hence have had each person to give his own receipt for what he received.
Trusting this will answer as well, I have the honor to be your obedient servant, R. J. B. Watson, Superintendent.
Hon. W. V. Gibson, Secy. State, Monrovia.
Copy.
Department of State, Monrovia, Oct. 10, 1901.
Sire,- Referring to my letter of August 20th, I have the honor to forward you herewith enclosed a letter from Superintendent Watson and the receipts.
This letter was delivered to me this morning.
I have the honor to be, Sir, Your obedient servant, W. V. Gibson, Acting Sect'y of State.
Hon. O. L. W. Smith U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General U.S. Legation, Monrovia.
